<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Soybean skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Soybean</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
</p>
<div class="dablink">"Soy" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Soy (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
</p>
<div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Taxobox/core&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Taxobox/core (page does not exist)">Template:Taxobox/core</a></div>
<p>The <b>soybean</b> (US) or <b>soya bean</b> (UK) (<i>Glycine max</i>)<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> is a species of <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legume</a> native to East Asia, widely grown for its edible <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">bean</a> which has numerous uses. The plant is classed as an <a href="/wiki/Oilseed" title="Oilseed" class="mw-redirect">oilseed</a> rather than a <a href="/wiki/Pulse_(legume)" title="Pulse (legume)">pulse</a> by the UN <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_and_Agricultural_Organization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food and Agricultural Organization (page does not exist)">Food and Agricultural Organization</a> (FAO).
</p><p>Fat-free (defatted) soybean meal is a significant and cheap source of protein for animal feeds and many <a href="/w/index.php?title=TV_dinner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TV dinner (page does not exist)">prepackaged meals</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soybean_oil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soybean oil (page does not exist)">soy vegetable oil</a> is another product of processing the soybean crop. For example, soybean products such as <a href="/wiki/Textured_vegetable_protein" title="Textured vegetable protein">textured vegetable protein</a> (TVP) are ingredients in many meat and dairy analogues.<sup id="cite_ref-Riaz2006_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Riaz2006-2">[2]</a></sup> Soybeans produce significantly more protein per acre than most other uses of land.<sup id="cite_ref-NSRL_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NSRL-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>Traditional nonfermented food uses of soybeans include <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, and from the latter <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">tofu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tofu_skin" title="Tofu skin">tofu skin</a>. Fermented foods include <a href="/wiki/Soy_sauce" title="Soy sauce">soy sauce</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermented_bean_paste&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermented bean paste (page does not exist)">fermented bean paste</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Natto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Natto (page does not exist)">natto</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a>, among others. The oil is used in many industrial applications. The main producers of soy are the United States (35%), Brazil (27%), Argentina (19%), China (6%) and India (4%).<sup id="cite_ref-United_States_Department_of_Agriculture_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_States_Department_of_Agriculture-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fas.usda.gov_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fas.usda.gov-5">[5]</a></sup> The beans contain significant amounts of <a href="/wiki/Phytic_acid" title="Phytic acid">phytic acid</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha-linolenic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha-linolenic acid (page does not exist)">alpha-linolenic acid</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isoflavone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isoflavone (page does not exist)">isoflavones</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2>
<p>The plant is sometimes referred to as <b>greater bean</b> (大豆 – Chinese <i>dàdòu</i> and Japanese <i>daizu</i>) or yellow bean (黄豆 - Chinese <i>huangdou</i>). Both the immature soybean and its dish are called <i><a href="/wiki/Edamame" title="Edamame">edamame</a></i> in Japan,<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> but in English, edamame refers only to a specific dish.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The genus name, <a href="/wiki/Glycine" title="Glycine">Glycine</a>, is the same as a simple amino acid.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Classification">Classification</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soybeanvarieties.jpg" title="File:Soybeanvarieties.jpg">File:Soybeanvarieties.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Varieties of soybeans are used for many purposes.</div></div></div>
<p>The genus name <a href="/wiki/Glycine_(plant)" title="Glycine (plant)"><i>Glycine</i></a> was originally introduced by <a href="/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus" title="Carl Linnaeus">Carl Linnaeus</a> (1737) in his first edition of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Genera_Plantarum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genera Plantarum (page does not exist)">Genera Plantarum</a></i>. The word glycine is derived from the Greek – <i>glykys</i> (sweet) and likely refers to the sweetness of the pear-shaped (<i>apios</i> in Greek) edible tubers produced by the native North American twining or climbing herbaceous <a href="/wiki/Yambean" title="Yambean" class="mw-redirect">yambean</a> <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legume</a>, <i>Glycine apios</i>, now known as <i><a href="/wiki/Apios_americana" title="Apios americana">Apios americana</a></i>. The cultivated soybean first appeared in <i><a href="/wiki/Species_Plantarum" title="Species Plantarum">Species Plantarum</a></i>, by Linnaeus, under the name <i><a href="/wiki/Phaseolus" title="Phaseolus">Phaseolus</a> max</i> L. The combination <i>Glycine max</i> (L.) Merr., as proposed by Merrill in 1917, has become the valid name for this useful plant.
</p><p>The genus <i>Glycine</i> Willd. is divided into two subgenera, <i>Glycine</i> and <i>Soja</i>. The subgenus <i>Soja</i> (Moench) F.J. Herm. includes the cultivated soybean, <i>Glycine max</i> (L.) Merr., and the wild soybean, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glycine_soja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glycine soja (page does not exist)">Glycine soja</a></i> Sieb. &amp; Zucc. Both species are <a href="/wiki/Annual_plant" title="Annual plant">annuals</a>. <i>Glycine soja</i> is the wild ancestor of <i>Glycine max</i>, and grows wild in China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Glycine_(plant)" title="Glycine (plant)">subgenus <i>Glycine</i></a> consists of at least 25 wild <a href="/w/index.php?title=Perennial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Perennial (page does not exist)">perennial</a> species: for example, <i>Glycine canescens</i> F.J. Herm. and <i>G. tomentella</i> Hayata, both found in Australia and Papua New Guinea.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>Perennial soybean {Neonotonia wightii} originated in Africa and is now a wide spread pasture crop in the Tropics.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Like some other crops of long domestication, the relationship of the modern soybean to wild-growing species can no longer be traced with any degree of certainty. It is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cultigen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cultigen (page does not exist)">cultural variety</a> with a very large number of cultivars.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Description_and_physical_characteristics">Description and physical characteristics</span></h2>
<p>Soy varies in growth and habit. The height of the plant varies from less than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.
</p><p>The pods, stems, and leaves are covered with fine brown or gray hairs. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leaf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leaf (page does not exist)">leaves</a> are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trifoliolate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trifoliolate (page does not exist)">trifoliolate</a>, having three to four <a href="/wiki/Leaflet" title="Leaflet">leaflets</a> per leaf, and the leaflets are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> broad. The leaves fall before the seeds are mature. The inconspicuous, self-fertile flowers are borne in the axil of the leaf and are white, pink or purple.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soybean_flowers.png" title="File:Soybean flowers.png">File:Soybean flowers.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Small, purple soybean flowers</div></div></div>
<p>The fruit is a hairy <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">pod</a> that grows in clusters of three to five, each pod is 3–8&#160;cm long (1–3&#160;in) and usually contains two to four (rarely more) <a href="/wiki/Seed" title="Seed">seeds</a> 5–11&#160;mm in diameter.
</p><p>Soybeans occur in various sizes, and in many <a href="/wiki/Husk" title="Husk">hull</a> or seed coat colors, including black, brown, blue, yellow, green and mottled. The hull of the mature bean is hard, water-resistant, and protects the <a href="/wiki/Cotyledon" title="Cotyledon">cotyledon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hypocotyl" title="Hypocotyl">hypocotyl</a> (or "germ") from damage. If the seed coat is cracked, the seed will not <a href="/wiki/Germinate" title="Germinate" class="mw-redirect">germinate</a>. The scar, visible on the seed coat, is called the hilum (colors include black, brown, buff, gray and yellow) and at one end of the hilum is the micropyle, or small opening in the seed coat which can allow the absorption of water for sprouting.
</p><p>Remarkably, seeds such as soybeans containing very high levels of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy protein (page does not exist)">protein</a> can undergo <a href="/wiki/Desiccation" title="Desiccation">desiccation</a>, yet survive and revive after water absorption. <a href="/w/index.php?title=A._Carl_Leopold&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A. Carl Leopold (page does not exist)">A. Carl Leopold</a>, son of <a href="/wiki/Aldo_Leopold" title="Aldo Leopold">Aldo Leopold</a>, began studying this capability at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boyce_Thompson_Institute_for_Plant_Research&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research (page does not exist)">Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cornell_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cornell University (page does not exist)">Cornell University</a> in the mid-1980s. He found soybeans and corn to have a range of soluble <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a> protecting the seed's cell viability.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Patents were awarded to him in the early 1990s on techniques for protecting "biological membranes" and proteins in the dry state. Compare to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tardigrades&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tardigrades (page does not exist)">tardigrades</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nitrogen-fixing_ability">Nitrogen-fixing ability</span></h2>
<p>Many legumes (<a href="/wiki/Alfalfa" title="Alfalfa">alfalfa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clover" title="Clover">clover</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pea" title="Pea">peas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a>, soybeans, <a href="/wiki/Peanut" title="Peanut">peanuts</a> and others) contain <a href="/wiki/Symbiosis" title="Symbiosis">symbiotic</a> bacteria called <i><a href="/wiki/Rhizobia" title="Rhizobia">Rhizobia</a></i> within <a href="/wiki/Root_nodule" title="Root nodule">nodules</a> of their <a href="/wiki/Root" title="Root">root systems</a>. These bacteria have the special ability of <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen_fixation" title="Nitrogen fixation">fixing nitrogen</a> from atmospheric, molecular nitrogen (N<sub>2</sub>) into <a href="/wiki/Ammonia" title="Ammonia">ammonia</a> (NH<sub>3</sub>).<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> The chemical reaction is:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> N<sub>2</sub> + 8 H<sup>+</sup> + 8 e<sup>−</sup> → 2 NH<sub>3</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Ammonia is then converted to another form, <a href="/wiki/Ammonium" title="Ammonium">ammonium</a> (NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup>), usable by (some) plants by the following reaction:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> NH<sub>3</sub> + H<sup>+</sup> → NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>This arrangement means that the root nodules are sources of nitrogen for legumes, making them relatively rich in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant_proteins&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant proteins (page does not exist)">plant proteins</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Chemical_composition_of_the_seed">Chemical composition of the seed</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
Together, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soybean_oil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soybean oil (page does not exist)">soybean oil</a> and protein content account for about 60% of dry soybeans by weight (protein at 40% and oil at 20%). The remainder consists of 35% carbohydrate and about 5% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ash_(analytical_chemistry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ash (analytical chemistry) (page does not exist)">ash</a>. Soybean cultivars comprise approximately 8% seed coat or hull, 90% <a href="/wiki/Cotyledons" title="Cotyledons" class="mw-redirect">cotyledons</a> and 2% <a href="/wiki/Hypocotyl" title="Hypocotyl">hypocotyl</a> axis or germ.
</p><p>Most <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy protein (page does not exist)">soy protein</a> is a relatively heat-stable storage protein. This heat stability enables soy food products requiring high temperature cooking, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">tofu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Textured_vegetable_protein" title="Textured vegetable protein">textured vegetable protein</a> (soy flour) to be made.
</p><p>The principal soluble <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a> of mature soybeans are the disaccharide <a href="/wiki/Sucrose" title="Sucrose">sucrose</a> (range 2.5–8.2%), the trisaccharide <a href="/wiki/Raffinose" title="Raffinose">raffinose</a> (0.1–1.0%) composed of one sucrose molecule connected to one molecule of <a href="/wiki/Galactose" title="Galactose">galactose</a>, and the tetrasaccharide <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stachyose&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stachyose (page does not exist)">stachyose</a> (1.4 to 4.1%) composed of one sucrose connected to two molecules of galactose.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> While the <a href="/wiki/Oligosaccharide" title="Oligosaccharide">oligosaccharides</a> raffinose and stachyose protect the viability of the soybean seed from desiccation (see above section on physical characteristics) they are not digestible sugars, so contribute to <a href="/wiki/Flatulence" title="Flatulence">flatulence</a> and abdominal discomfort in humans and other <a href="/wiki/Monogastric" title="Monogastric">monogastric</a> animals, comparable to the disaccharide <a href="/wiki/Trehalose" title="Trehalose">trehalose</a>. Undigested oligosaccharides are broken down in the intestine by native microbes, producing gases such as <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methane (page does not exist)">methane</a>.
</p><p>Since soluble soy carbohydrates are found in the whey and are broken down during fermentation, soy concentrate, soy protein isolates, tofu, soy sauce, and sprouted soybeans are without flatus activity. On the other hand, there may be some beneficial effects to ingesting oligosaccharides such as <a href="/wiki/Raffinose" title="Raffinose">raffinose</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stachyose&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stachyose (page does not exist)">stachyose</a>, namely, encouraging indigenous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bifidobacterium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bifidobacterium (page does not exist)">bifidobacteria</a> in the colon against putrefactive bacteria.
</p><p>The insoluble carbohydrates in soybeans consist of the complex polysaccharides <a href="/wiki/Cellulose" title="Cellulose">cellulose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hemicellulose" title="Hemicellulose">hemicellulose</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pectin" title="Pectin">pectin</a>. The majority of soybean carbohydrates can be classed as belonging to <a href="/wiki/Dietary_fiber" title="Dietary fiber">dietary fiber</a>.
</p><p>Within <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soybean_oil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soybean oil (page does not exist)">soybean oil</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Lipid" title="Lipid">lipid</a> portion of the seed is contained four <a href="/w/index.php?title=Phytosterols&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phytosterols (page does not exist)">phytosterols</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stigmasterol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stigmasterol (page does not exist)">stigmasterol</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sitosterol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sitosterol (page does not exist)">sitosterol</a>,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Campesterol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Campesterol (page does not exist)">campesterol</a>,and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brassicasterol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brassicasterol (page does not exist)">brassicasterol</a>  accounting for  about 2.5% of the lipid fraction; and which can be converted into <a href="/wiki/Steroid_hormones" title="Steroid hormones" class="mw-redirect">steroid hormones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Saponins" title="Saponins" class="mw-redirect">Saponins</a>, a class of natural <a href="/wiki/Surfactants" title="Surfactants" class="mw-redirect">surfactants</a> (soaps), are sterols that are present naturally in a wide variety of food-plants: vegetables, legumes, and cereals–ranging from beans and spinach to tomatoes, potatoes and oats. Whole soybeans contain from 0.17 to 6.16% <a href="/wiki/Saponins" title="Saponins" class="mw-redirect">saponins</a>, 0.35 to 2.3% in defatted soy flour and 0.06 to 1.9% in tofu. Legumes such as soybean and chickpeas are the major source of saponins in the human diet. Sources of non-dietary saponins include alfalfa, sunflower, herbs and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexican_barbasco_trade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexican barbasco trade (page does not exist)">barbasco</a>.
</p><p>Soy contains isoflavones like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genistein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genistein (page does not exist)">genistein</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daidzein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daidzein (page does not exist)">daidzein</a>. It also contains <a href="/w/index.php?title=Glycitein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glycitein (page does not exist)">glycitein</a>, an O-methylated isoflavone which accounts for 5–10% of the total isoflavones in soy food products. Glycitein is a <a href="/wiki/Phytoestrogen" title="Phytoestrogen" class="mw-redirect">phytoestrogen</a> with weak estrogenic activity, comparable to that of the other soy isoflavones.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition">Nutrition</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Further2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Further2 (page does not exist)">Template:Further2</a>
For human consumption, soybeans must be cooked with "wet" heat to destroy the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trypsin_inhibitor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trypsin inhibitor (page does not exist)">trypsin inhibitors</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Serine_protease_inhibitor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Serine protease inhibitor (page does not exist)">serine protease inhibitors</a>). Raw soybeans, including the immature green form, are toxic to humans, swine, chickens, and in fact, all <a href="/wiki/Monogastric" title="Monogastric">monogastric</a> animals.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>Soybeans are considered by many agencies to be a source of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Complete_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complete protein (page does not exist)">complete protein</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FDA_Claims_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FDA_Claims-20">[20]</a></sup> A complete protein is one that contains significant amounts of all the <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acid" title="Essential amino acid">essential amino acids</a> that must be provided to the <a href="/wiki/Human_body" title="Human body">human body</a> because of the body's inability to <a href="/wiki/Biosynthesis" title="Biosynthesis">synthesize</a> them. For this reason, soy is a good source of protein, amongst many others, for vegetarians and <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">vegans</a> or for people who want to reduce the amount of meat they eat. According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_and_Drug_Administration_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food and Drug Administration (United States) (page does not exist)">US Food and Drug Administration</a>:
</p>
<blockquote>Soy protein products can be good substitutes for animal products because, unlike some other beans, soy offers a 'complete' protein profile. ... Soy protein products can replace animal-based foods—which also have complete proteins but tend to contain more fat, especially saturated fat—without requiring major adjustments elsewhere in the diet.<sup id="cite_ref-FDA_Claims_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FDA_Claims-20">[20]</a></sup></blockquote>
<p>The gold standard for measuring protein quality, since 1990, is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=PDCAAS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PDCAAS (page does not exist)">Protein Digestibility Corrected Amino Acid Score</a> (PDCAAS) and by this criterion soy protein is the nutritional equivalent of meat, eggs, and <a href="/wiki/Casein" title="Casein">casein</a> for human growth and health. Soybean protein isolate has a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biological_value&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biological value (page does not exist)">biological value</a> of 74, whole soybeans 96, soybean milk 91, and eggs 97.<sup id="cite_ref-1991Report_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1991Report-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy protein (page does not exist)">Soy protein</a> is essentially identical to the protein of other <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legume</a> seeds and <a href="/wiki/Pulses" title="Pulses" class="mw-redirect">pulses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Moreover, soybeans can produce at least twice as much protein per acre than any other major vegetable or grain crop besides <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hempnut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hempnut (page does not exist)">hemp</a>, five to 10 times more protein per acre than land set aside for grazing animals to make milk, and up to 15 times more protein per acre than land set aside for meat production.<sup id="cite_ref-NSRL_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NSRL-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Comparison_to_other_major_staple_foods">Comparison to other major staple foods</span></h4>
<p>The following table shows the nutrient content of green soybean and other major staple foods, each in respective raw form. Raw soybeans, however, aren't edible and cannot be digested. These must be sprouted, or prepared and cooked for human consumption. In sprouted and cooked form, the relative nutritional and anti-nutritional contents of each of these grains is remarkably different from that of raw form of these grains reported in this table. The nutritional value of soybean and each cooked staple depends on the pre-processing and the method of cooking: boiling, frying, roasting, baking, etc.
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Comparison_of_major_staple_foods&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Comparison of major staple foods (page does not exist)">Template:Comparison of major staple foods</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_near_universality_of_soy_protein">The near universality of soy protein</span></h2>
<p>All <a href="/wiki/Spermatophytes" title="Spermatophytes" class="mw-redirect">spermatophytes</a> except for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grass&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grass (page does not exist)">grass</a> <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">cereal</a> family
contain soybean-like 7S (vicilin) and/or 11S (legumin) seed storage globulin proteins. {Oats and rice, are anomalous in that they also contain a majority of soybean protein.} <sup id="cite_ref-Seed_Proteins_1999_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seed_Proteins_1999-25">[25]</a></sup> Cocoa for example contains the 7S globulin which contributes to cocoa/chocolate taste and aroma;<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> whereas coffee beans(coffee grounds) contain the 11S globulin responsible for coffee's aroma and flavor.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vicilin and legumin proteins belong to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cupin_superfamily&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cupin superfamily (page does not exist)">cupin superfamily</a> a large and functionally immensely diverse 'superfamily' of proteins that have a common origin and whose evolution can be followed from bacteria to eukaryotes including animals and higher plants.
</p><p>2S <a href="/wiki/Albumins" title="Albumins" class="mw-redirect">albumins</a> form a major group of homologous storage proteins in many <a href="/wiki/Dicot" title="Dicot" class="mw-redirect">dicot</a> species and in some <a href="/wiki/Monocots" title="Monocots" class="mw-redirect">monocots</a> but not grasses(cereals).<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-31">[31]</a></sup> 2S albumin are grouped in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prolamin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prolamin (page does not exist)">prolamin</a> superfamily,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> other allergenic proteins included in this 'superfamily' are the non-specific lipid transfer proteins, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha_amylase&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha amylase (page does not exist)">alpha amylase</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trypsin_inhibitor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trypsin inhibitor (page does not exist)">trypsin inhibitor</a>; And the prolamin storage proteins of cereals and grasses.<sup id="cite_ref-Seed_Proteins_1999_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seed_Proteins_1999-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Peanut" title="Peanut">Peanut</a>(peanut butter) for instance contain 20% 2S albumin,but only 6% 7S globulin and 74% 11S.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-31">[31]</a></sup> It is the high 2S albumin and low 7S globulin that is responsible for the relatively low quality (low lysine) of peanut protein compared to soy protein. Cereal storage prolamins are likewise low in lysine the most important, critical and first limiting amino acid. Peanut butter and wheat bread, therefore, do not complement each other as they each suffer from low lysine.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultivation">Cultivation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2005soyabean.PNG" title="File:2005soyabean.PNG">File:2005soyabean.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Soybean output in 2005</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Agricultural_production_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Agricultural production box (page does not exist)">Template:Agricultural production box</a>
Soybeans are a globally important crop, providing oil and protein. In the United States, the bulk of the harvest is solvent-extracted with <a href="/wiki/Hexane" title="Hexane">hexane</a>, and the "toasted" defatted soymeal (50% protein) then makes possible the raising of farm animals (e.g. chicken, hog, turkey) on an industrial scale never before seen in human history. A very small proportion of the crop is consumed directly by humans.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Soybean products do, however, appear in a large variety of processed foods.
</p><p>During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, soybeans became important in both North America and Europe chiefly as substitutes for other protein foods and as a source of edible oil. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the soybean was discovered as fertilizer by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">United States Department of Agriculture</a>. In the 1960–1 Dillon round of the <a href="/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Tariffs_and_Trade" title="General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade">General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade</a> (GATT), the United States secured tariff-free access for its soybeans to the European market. In the 1960s, the United States exported over 90% of the world's soybeans.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> By 2005, the top soybeans exporters were Argentina (39% of world soybean exports), United States (37%) and Brazil (16%), while top importers were China (41% of world soybean imports), European Union (22%), Japan (6%) and Mexico (6%).<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>Cultivation is successful in climates with hot summers, with optimum growing conditions in mean temperatures of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>; temperatures of below 20 °C and over 40 °C (68 °F, 104 °F) stunt growth significantly. They can grow in a wide range of soils, with optimum growth in moist alluvial soils with a good organic content. Soybeans, like most legumes, perform <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen_fixation" title="Nitrogen fixation">nitrogen fixation</a> by establishing a <a href="/wiki/Symbiotic" title="Symbiotic" class="mw-redirect">symbiotic</a> relationship with the bacterium <i><a href="/wiki/Rhizobia" title="Rhizobia">Bradyrhizobium japonicum</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Synonymy" title="Synonymy" class="mw-redirect">syn.</a> <i>Rhizobium japonicum</i>; Jordan 1982). For best results, though, an inoculum of the correct strain of bacteria should be mixed with the soybean (or any legume) seed before planting. Modern crop <a href="/wiki/Cultivar" title="Cultivar">cultivars</a> generally reach a height of around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, and take 80–120&#160;days from sowing to harvesting.
</p><p>The U.S., Argentina, Brazil, China and India are the world's largest soybean producers and represent more than 90% of global soybean production.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The U.S. produced 75&#160;million tons of soybeans in 2000, of which more than one-third was exported. In the 2010–2011 production year, this figure is expected to be over 90 million tons.<sup id="cite_ref-fas.usda.gov_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fas.usda.gov-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>The average worldwide yield for soybean crops, in 2010, was 2.5 tonnes per hectare. The three largest producers had an average nationwide soybean crop yields of about 3 tonnes per hectare. The most productive soybean farms in the world in 2010 were in Turkey, with a nationwide average farm yield of 3.7 tonnes per hectare.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> The world record for soybean yield is 10.8 tonnes per hectare, demonstrated in 2010 by Kip Cullers, a farmer in Purdy, <a href="/wiki/Missouri" title="Missouri">Missouri</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> Kip Cullers claims the secret to his record breaking soybean crop yields year after year is attention to detail, proactive management style, irrigation, herbicides, keeping plants healthy and stress free for the entire growing season.
</p><p>Environmental groups, such as <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace" title="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Wide Fund for Nature (page does not exist)">WWF</a>, have reported soybean cultivation and the probability of increased soybean cultivation in Brazil has destroyed huge areas of <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, and is encouraging further <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">deforestation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>American soil scientist Andrew McClung, who first showed that the ecologically biodiverse savannah of the <a href="/wiki/Cerrado" title="Cerrado">Cerrado</a> region of Brazil could grow profitable soybeans, was awarded the 2006 <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Prize" title="World Food Prize">World Food Prize</a> on October 19, 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>Human sewage <a href="/wiki/Sludge" title="Sludge">sludge</a> can be used as fertilizer to grow soybeans. Soybeans grown in sewage sludge likely contain elevated concentrations of metals.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Soybean plants are vulnerable to a wide range of bacterial diseases, fungal diseases, viral diseases and parasites. One important pest is the <a href="/wiki/Helicoverpa_zea" title="Helicoverpa zea">corn earworm moth</a>, which is the most common and destructive pest of soybean growth in Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Soybeans can be grown organically, that is, without the use of synthetic pesticides and fertilizers. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p>Soybeans were a crucial crop in East Asia long before written records began.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> They remain a major crop in the United States, Brazil, Argentina, India, China, and <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a>. Prior to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (food) (page does not exist)">fermented</a> products such as <a href="/wiki/Soy_sauce" title="Soy sauce">soy sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Natto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Natto (page does not exist)">natto</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Miso" title="Miso">miso</a>, soy was considered sacred for its beneficial effects in <a href="/wiki/Crop_rotation" title="Crop rotation">crop rotation</a>.
</p><p>The plants would be plowed under to clear the field of food crops.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Soy was first introduced to Europe in the early 18th century and to British colonies in North America in 1765, where it was first grown for hay. <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> wrote a letter in 1770 mentioning sending soybeans home from England. Soybeans did not become an important crop outside of Asia until about 1910. In America, soy was considered an industrial product only, and was not used as a food prior to the 1920s. Soy was introduced to Africa from China in the late 19th century, and is now widespread across the continent.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia">Asia</span></h3>
<p>The wild ancestor of the soybean is <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glycine_soja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glycine soja (page does not exist)">Glycine soja</a></i> (previously called <i>G. ussuriensis</i>), a legume native to central China.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-47">[47]</a></sup>
According to the ancient Chinese myth, in 2853 BCE, the legendary <a href="/wiki/Shennong" title="Shennong">Emperor Shennong</a> of China proclaimed that five plants were sacred: soybeans, rice, wheat, barley, and <a href="/wiki/Millet" title="Millet">millet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
Cultivation of soybeans was long confined chiefly to East Asia, but gradually spread to other countries during the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>The origin of soy bean cultivation remains scientifically debated. Recent research indicates that seeding of wild forms started early (before 5000 BCE) in multiple locations through China, Korea and Japan <sup id="cite_ref-PLOSONE_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PLOSONE-50">[50]</a></sup>     
The oldest preserved soybeans resembling modern varieties in size and shape were found in <a href="/wiki/Archaeological_site" title="Archaeological site">archaeological sites</a> in <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a> dated about 1000 BCE <sup id="cite_ref-stark_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stark-51">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">Radiocarbon dating</a> of soybean samples recovered through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flotation_(archaeology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flotation (archaeology) (page does not exist)">flotation</a> during excavations at the Early <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mumun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mumun (page does not exist)">Mumun</a> period Okbang site in Korea indicated soybean was cultivated as a food crop in around 1000–900 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-stark_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stark-51">[51]</a></sup> Soy bean from the Jomon period in Japan from 3000 BCE <sup id="cite_ref-PLOSONE_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PLOSONE-50">[50]</a></sup> are also significantly larger than wild varieties.<sup id="cite_ref-PLOSONE_50-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PLOSONE-50">[50]</a></sup>
Early cultivation of soy beans in China was localized and not intensive, e.g. soy bean was unknown in South China before the <a href="/wiki/Han_Dynasty" title="Han Dynasty">Han period</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-PLOSONE_50-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PLOSONE-50">[50]</a></sup> using varieties with small wild size beans. Only when new soy bean cultivars became introduced into Zhou China from the "north-east" (as cited by contemporary literature) around 510 BCE an agricultural revolution was triggered eventually making soy beans part the staple diet.
<sup id="cite_ref-HOPT_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HOPT-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>From about the first century CE to the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a> (15–16th century), soybeans were introduced into several countries, such as India, Japan, Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia, Malaysia, Burma, Taiwan and Nepal. This spread was due to the establishment of sea and land trade routes. The earliest Japanese textual reference to the soybean is in the classic <i><a href="/wiki/Kojiki" title="Kojiki">Kojiki</a></i> (Records of Ancient Matters), which was completed in 712 CE.
</p><p>Many people have claimed soybeans in Asia were historically only used after a fermentation process, which lowers the high <a href="/wiki/Phytoestrogen" title="Phytoestrogen" class="mw-redirect">phytoestrogens</a> content found in the raw plant. However, terms similar to "<a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>" have been in use since 82 CE,<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> and there is evidence of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">tofu</a> consumption that dates to 220.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">United States</span></h3>
<p>Soybeans were introduced to America in 1765 by Samuel Bowen, a former <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> sailor who had visited China,<sup id="cite_ref-Hymowitz1983_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hymowitz1983-55">[55]</a></sup> in conjunction with <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Flint_(merchant)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Flint (merchant) (page does not exist)">James Flint</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
the first Englishman legally permitted by the Chinese authorities to learn <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">Chinese</a>. Bowen grew soy near <a href="/wiki/Savannah,_Georgia" title="Savannah, Georgia">Savannah, Georgia</a>, possibly using funds from Flint, and even made soy sauce for sale to England.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Soy took on a very important role in the United States after <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>. During the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a>, the drought-stricken (<a href="/wiki/Dust_Bowl" title="Dust Bowl">Dust Bowl</a>) regions of the United States were able to use soy to regenerate their soil because of its nitrogen-fixing properties. Farms were increasing production to meet with government demands, and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Ford" title="Henry Ford">Henry Ford</a> was a great leader of the soybean industry.
</p><p>In 1932–33, the Ford Motor Company spent approximately $1,250,000 on soybean research. By 1935, every Ford car had soy involved in its manufacture. For example, soybean oil was used to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_paint&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy paint (page does not exist)">paint</a> the automobiles,<sup id="cite_ref-Schwarcz_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schwarcz-58">[58]</a></sup> as well as fluid for shock absorbers. Ford's involvement with the soybean opened many doors for agriculture and industry to be linked more strongly than ever before.
</p><p>Henry Ford promoted the soybean, helping to develop uses for it both in food and in industrial products, even demonstrating auto body panels made of soy-based plastics. Ford's interest led to two <a href="/wiki/Bushel" title="Bushel">bushels</a> (120 pounds)<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> of soybeans being used in each Ford car, as well as products like the first commercial <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, ice cream and all-vegetable nondairy whipped topping. The Ford development of so-called soy-based plastics was based on the addition of soybean flour and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wood_flour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wood flour (page does not exist)">wood flour</a> to <a href="/wiki/Polymer#Historical_development" title="Polymer">phenol formaldehyde plastics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> A prototype vehicle, colloquially titled the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Soybean_Car&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soybean Car (page does not exist)">Soybean Car</a>", was built in 1941 out of such plastics.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1931, Ford hired chemists <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boyer_(chemist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Boyer (chemist) (page does not exist)">Robert Boyer</a> and Frank Calvert to produce <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_silk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Artificial silk (page does not exist)">artificial silk</a>. They succeeded in making a textile fiber of spun soy protein fibers, hardened or tanned in a <a href="/wiki/Formaldehyde" title="Formaldehyde">formaldehyde</a> bath, which was given the name <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azlon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azlon (page does not exist)">Azlon</a>. It was usable in the making of suits, felt hats, and overcoats. Though pilot production of Azlon reached 5000&#160;pounds per day in 1940, it never reached the commercial market; Dupont's nylon was the winner in the quest to produce artificial silk.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="South_America">South America</span></h3>
<p>The soybean first arrived in South America in Argentina in 1882.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">Africa</span></h3>
<p>The soybean first arrived in Africa in Egypt in 1857.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia">Australia</span></h3>
<p>Wild soybeans were discovered in northeastern Australia in 1770 by explorers Banks and Solander. In 1804, the first soyfood product ("Fine India Soy" [sauce]) was sold in Sydney. In 1879, the first domesticated soybeans arrived in Australia, a gift of the Minister of the Interior Department, Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Canada">Canada</span></h3>
<p>In 1831, the first soy product ("A few dozen India Soy" [sauce]) arrived in Canada. Soybeans were probably first cultivated in Canada by 1855, and definitely in 1895 at Ontario Agricultural College. A comprehensive history of soy in Canada (1,060 p., 2,336 references) is available online.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Caribbean_and_West_Indies">Caribbean and West Indies</span></h3>
<p>The soybean arrived in the Caribbean in the form of soy sauce made by Samuel Bowen in Savannah, Georgia, in 1767. It remains only a minor crop there, but its uses for human food are growing steadily. A comprehensive history of soybeans and soyfoods in this region is available free online.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Central_Asia">Central Asia</span></h3>
<p>The soybean is first in cultivated Transcaucasia in Central Asia in 1876, by the Dungans. This region has never been important for soybean production. A comprehensive history of soybeans and soyfoods in this region is available online.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mexico_and_Central_America">Mexico and Central America</span></h3>
<p>The first reliable reference to the soybean in this region dates from Mexico in 1877. A comprehensive history of soybeans and soyfoods in this region is available online.<sup id="cite_ref-book-128_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-book-128-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Southeast_Asia">Southeast Asia</span></h3>
<p>By the 13th century, the soybean had arrived in Indonesia; it probably arrived much earlier, carried by traders or merchants from southern China.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="South_Asia_and_Indian_Subcontinent">South Asia and Indian Subcontinent</span></h3>
<p>By the 1600s, soy sauce was being disseminated from southern Japan throughout this region by the Dutch East India Co. (VOC). The soybean probably arrived from southern China, moving southward into northern India.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Genetic_modification">Genetic modification</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Multicolor_soybeans_in_Hale_Township.jpg" title="File:Multicolor soybeans in Hale Township.jpg">File:Multicolor soybeans in Hale Township.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Different varieties of soybeans being grown together</div></div></div>
<p>Soybeans are one of the "<a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotech</a> food" crops that have been <a href="/wiki/Genetically_modified_food" title="Genetically modified food">genetically modified</a>, and genetically modified soybeans are being used in an increasing number of products. In 1995, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Monsanto_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Monsanto Company (page does not exist)">Monsanto Company</a> introduced <a href="/wiki/Genetically_modified_crops" title="Genetically modified crops">glyphosate-tolerant</a> soybeans that have been genetically modified to be resistant to Monsanto's <a href="/wiki/Glyphosate" title="Glyphosate">glyphosate</a> herbicides through substitution of the <i><a href="/wiki/Agrobacterium" title="Agrobacterium">Agrobacterium</a> sp.</i> (strain CP4) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gene&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gene (page does not exist)">gene</a> EPSP (5-enolpyruvyl shikimic acid-3-phosphate) synthase. The substituted version is not sensitive to <a href="/wiki/Glyphosate" title="Glyphosate">glyphosate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1997, about 8% of all soybeans cultivated for the commercial market in the United States were genetically modified. In 2010, the figure was 93%.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> As with other glyphosate-tolerant crops, concern is expressed over damage to <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> A 2003 study<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> concluded the RR gene had been bred into so many different soybean cultivars, there had been little decline in genetic diversity, but "diversity was limited among elite lines from some companies".
</p><p>The widespread use of such types of GM soybeans in the Americas has caused problems with exports to some regions. GM crops require extensive certification before they can be legally imported into the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, where there is considerable supplier and consumer reluctance to use GM products for consumer or animal use. Difficulties with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Co-existence_of_genetically_modified_and_conventional_crops_and_derived_food_and_feed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Co-existence of genetically modified and conventional crops and derived food and feed (page does not exist)">coexistence</a> and subsequent traces of cross-contamination of non-GM stocks have caused shipments to be rejected and have put a premium on non-GM soy.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2006 <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">United States Department of Agriculture</a> report found the adoption of genetically engineered (GE) soy, corn and cotton reduced the amount of pesticides used overall, but did result in a slightly greater amount of <a href="/wiki/Herbicide" title="Herbicide">herbicides</a> used for soy specifically. The use of GE soy was also associated with greater <a href="/wiki/No-till_farming" title="No-till farming">conservation tillage</a>, indirectly leading to better soil conservation, as well as increased income from off-farming sources due to the greater ease with which the crops can be managed. Though the overall estimated benefits of the adoption of GE soybeans in the United States was $310&#160;million, the majority of this benefit was experienced by the companies selling the seeds (40%), followed by biotechnology firms (28%) and farmers (20%).<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, a team of American scientists announced they had sequenced the soybean genome – the first legume to be sequenced.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Uses">Uses</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TofuWithSoySauceAndCarrot.jpg" title="File:TofuWithSoySauceAndCarrot.jpg">File:TofuWithSoySauceAndCarrot.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Tofu and soy sauce</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:JapaneseSoybeanMeat.jpg" title="File:JapaneseSoybeanMeat.jpg">File:JapaneseSoybeanMeat.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Japanese soybean meat</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chives_Cream_Sheese.jpg" title="File:Chives Cream Sheese.jpg">File:Chives Cream Sheese.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Open package of a soy-based cream cheese alternative with chives</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soy_milk_I.jpg" title="File:Soy milk I.jpg">File:Soy milk I.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A Malaysian <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">Soy milk</a> carton, and a glass of the beverage.</div></div></div>
<p>Approximately 85% of the world's soybean crop is processed into soybean meal and vegetable oil.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Soybeans can be broadly classified as "vegetable" (garden) or field (oil) types. Vegetable types cook more easily, have a mild, nutty flavor, better texture, are larger in size, higher in protein, and lower in oil than field types. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">Tofu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a> producers prefer the higher protein cultivars bred from vegetable soybeans originally brought to the United States in the late 1930s. The "garden" cultivars are generally not suitable for mechanical combine harvesting because there is a tendency for the pods to shatter upon reaching maturity.
</p><p>Among the legumes, the soybean, also classed as an oilseed, is preeminent for its high (38–45%) <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">protein</a> content as well as its high (approximately 20%) oil content. Soybeans are the second-most valuable agricultural export in the United States behind corn. The bulk of the soybean crop is grown for oil production, with the high-protein defatted and "toasted" soy meal used as livestock feed. A smaller percentage of soybeans are used directly for human consumption.
</p><p>Immature soybeans may be boiled whole in their green pods and served with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edible_salt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edible salt (page does not exist)">salt</a>, under the Japanese name <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a>. In English, these soybeans are generally known as "edamame" or "green vegetable soybeans".
</p><p>In China, Japan, and <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a>, the bean and products made from it are a popular part of the diet. The Chinese invented tofu (豆腐 <i>dòufu</i>),{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} and also made use of several varieties of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soybean_paste&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soybean paste (page does not exist)">soybean paste</a> as seasonings. Japanese foods made from soya include <i><a href="/wiki/Miso" title="Miso">miso</a></i> (味噌), <i><a href="/wiki/Natt%C5%8D" title="Nattō">nattō</a></i> (納豆), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kinako&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kinako (page does not exist)">kinako</a></i> (黄粉) and <i>edamame</i> (枝豆). Also many kinds of food are produced using tofu such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atsuage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atsuage (page does not exist)">atsuage</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aburaage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aburaage (page does not exist)">aburaage</a>, and so on. In <a href="/wiki/Korean_cuisine" title="Korean cuisine">Korean cuisine</a>, soybean sprouts, called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kongnamul&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kongnamul (page does not exist)">kongnamul</a></i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ko:%EC%BD%A9%EB%82%98%EB%AC%BC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ko:콩나물 (page does not exist)">콩나물</a>), are also used in a variety of dishes, and are also the base ingredient in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Doenjang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doenjang (page does not exist)">doenjang</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheonggukjang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheonggukjang (page does not exist)">cheonggukjang</a></i> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kanjang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kanjang (page does not exist)"><i>ganjang</i></a>. In Vietnam, soybeans are used to make soybean paste- <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=T%C6%B0%C6%A1ng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tương (page does not exist)">tương</a></i> in the North with the most popular products are <i>tương Bần</i>, <i>tương Nam Đàn</i>, <i>tương Cự Đà</i> as a garnish for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ph%E1%BB%9F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phở (page does not exist)">phở</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=G%E1%BB%8Fi_cu%E1%BB%91n&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gỏi cuốn (page does not exist)">gỏi cuốn</a></i> dishes, tofu (<i>đậu hũ</i> or <i>đậu phụ</i> or <i>tàu hũ</i>), soya sauce (<i>nước tương</i>, literally: soya water), soya milk (<i>nước đậu</i> in the North or <i>sữa đậu nành</i> in the South), and <i>đậu hũ nước đường</i> (tofu sweet soup).
</p><p>The beans can be processed in a variety of ways. Common forms of soy (or soya) include <a href="#Meal">soy meal</a>, <a href="#Flour">soy flour</a>, soy milk, tofu, <a href="/wiki/Textured_vegetable_protein" title="Textured vegetable protein">textured vegetable protein</a> (TVP, which is made into a wide variety of <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_food" title="Vegetarian food" class="mw-redirect">vegetarian foods</a>, some of them intended to imitate meat), <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a>, soy <a href="/wiki/Lecithin" title="Lecithin">lecithin</a> and <a href="#Oil">soybean oil</a>. Soybeans are also the primary ingredient involved in the production of <a href="/wiki/Soy_sauce" title="Soy sauce">soy sauce</a> (<i>shoyu</i>).
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Archer_Daniels_Midland" title="Archer Daniels Midland">Archer Daniels Midland</a> (ADM) is among the largest processors of soybeans and soy products. ADM, along with <a href="/wiki/Dow_Chemical_Company" title="Dow Chemical Company">Dow Chemical Company</a>, <a href="/wiki/DuPont" title="DuPont">DuPont</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Monsanto_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Monsanto Company (page does not exist)">Monsanto Company</a>, support the industry trade associations United Soybean Board and Soyfoods Association of North America. These trade associations have increased the consumption of soy products dramatically in recent years.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Oil">Oil</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Soybean seed contains about 19% oil. To extract soybean oil from seed, the soybeans are cracked, adjusted for moisture content, rolled into flakes and solvent-extracted with commercial hexane. The oil is then refined, blended for different applications, and sometimes hydrogenated. Soybean oils, both liquid and partially hydrogenated, are exported abroad, sold as "vegetable oil", or end up in a wide variety of processed foods. The remaining soybean meal is used mainly as animal feed.<sup id="cite_ref-Lusas_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lusas-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Meal">Meal</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Soybean meal is the material remaining after solvent extraction of oil from soybean flakes, with a 50% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy protein (page does not exist)">soy protein</a> content. The meal is 'toasted' (a <a href="/wiki/Misnomer" title="Misnomer">misnomer</a> because the heat treatment is with moist steam) and ground in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hammer_mill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hammer mill (page does not exist)">hammer mill</a>. Soybean meal is an essential element of the American production method of growing farm animals, such as poultry and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Domestic_pig&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Domestic pig (page does not exist)">swine</a>, on an industrial scale that began in the 1930s; and more recently the <a href="/wiki/Aquaculture" title="Aquaculture">aquaculture</a> of <a href="/wiki/Catfish" title="Catfish">catfish</a>. Ninety-eight percent of the U.S. soybean crop is used for livestock feed.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-47">[47]</a></sup> Soybean meal is also used in lower-end <a href="/wiki/Dog_food" title="Dog food">dog foods</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lusas_80-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lusas-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flour">Flour</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a> 
Soy flour refers to soybeans ground finely enough to pass through a 100-mesh or smaller screen where special care was taken during desolventizing (not toasted) to minimize <a href="/wiki/Denaturation_(biochemistry)" title="Denaturation (biochemistry)">denaturation</a> of the protein to retain a high <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_dispersibility_index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein dispersibility index (page does not exist)">protein dispersibility index</a>, for uses such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_extrusion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food extrusion (page does not exist)">food extrusion</a> of <a href="/wiki/Textured_vegetable_protein" title="Textured vegetable protein">textured vegetable protein</a>. It is the starting material for production of soy concentrate and soy protein isolate.
</p><p>Soy flour is made by roasting the soybean, removing the coat, and grinding into a flour. Soy flour is manufactured with different fat levels.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>  Alternatively, <b>raw</b> soy flour omits the roasting step.
</p>
<ul>
<li> Defatted soy flour is obtained from <a href="/wiki/Solvent" title="Solvent">solvent</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Extraction_(chemistry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Extraction (chemistry) (page does not exist)">extracted</a> flakes, and contains less than 1% oil.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</li>
<li> "Natural or full-fat soy flour is made from unextracted, dehulled beans, and contains about 18% to 20% oil."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Its high oil content requires the use of a specialized Alpine Fine Impact Mill to grind rather than the usual <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hammer_mill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hammer mill (page does not exist)">hammer mill</a>. Full-fat soy flour has a lower protein concentration then defatted flour.
</li>
<li> Low-fat soy flour is made by adding some oil back into defatted soy flour. Fat levels range from 4.5% to 9%.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</li>
<li> High-fat soy flour can also be produced by adding back soybean oil to defatted flour at the level of 15%.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_lecithin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy lecithin (page does not exist)">Soy lecithin</a> can be added (up to 15%) to soy flour to make lecithinated soy flour. It increases dispersibility and gives it emulsifying properties.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Soy flour has 50% protein and 5% fiber. It has higher levels of protein, thiamine, riboflavin, phosphorus, calcium, and iron than <a href="/wiki/Wheat_flour" title="Wheat flour">wheat flour</a>. It does not contain <a href="/wiki/Gluten" title="Gluten">gluten</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> As a result, <a href="/wiki/Yeast" title="Yeast">yeast</a>-raised <a href="/wiki/Bread" title="Bread">breads</a> made with soy flour are dense in texture. Among many uses, soy flour thickens sauces, prevents <a href="/w/index.php?title=Staling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Staling (page does not exist)">staling</a> in baked food, and reduces oil absorption during frying. Baking food with soy flour gives it tenderness, moistness, a rich color, and a fine texture.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Soy grits are similar to soy flour except the soybeans have been toasted and cracked into coarse pieces.
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kinako&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kinako (page does not exist)">Kinako</a></i> is a soy flour used in <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">Japanese cuisine</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Resize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Resize (page does not exist)">Template:Resize</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infant_formula">Infant formula</span></h3>
<p>Soy-based <a href="/wiki/Infant_formula" title="Infant formula">infant formula</a> (SBIF) is sometimes given to infants who are not being strictly breastfed; it can be useful for infants who are either allergic to pasteurized cow milk proteins or who are being fed a <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">vegan</a> diet. It is sold in powdered, ready-to-feed, and concentrated liquid forms.
</p><p>Some reviews have expressed the opinion that more research is needed to determine what effect the phytoestrogens in soybeans may have on infants.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> Diverse studies have concluded there are no adverse effects in human growth, development, or reproduction as a result of the consumption of soy-based infant formula.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nutri_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nutri-84">[84]</a></sup> One of these studies, published in the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Journal_of_Nutrition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Journal of Nutrition (page does not exist)">Journal of Nutrition</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Nutri_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nutri-84">[84]</a></sup> concludes that there are:
</p>
<blockquote>... no clinical concerns with respect to nutritional adequacy, sexual development, neurobehavioral development, immune development, or thyroid disease. SBIFs provide complete nutrition that adequately supports normal infant growth and development. FDA has accepted SBIFs as safe for use as the sole source of nutrition.</blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Meat_and_dairy_substitutes_and_extenders">Meat and dairy substitutes and extenders</span></h3>
<p>Soybeans can be processed to produce a texture and appearance similar to many other foods. For example, soybeans are the primary ingredient in many <a href="/wiki/Dairy_product" title="Dairy product">dairy product</a> substitutes (e.g., <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margarine" title="Margarine">margarine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_ice_cream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy ice cream (page does not exist)">soy ice cream</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_yogurt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy yogurt (page does not exist)">soy yogurt</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_cheese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy cheese (page does not exist)">soy cheese</a>, and soy cream cheese) and meat substitutes (e.g. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Veggie_burgers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Veggie burgers (page does not exist)">veggie burgers</a>). These substitutes are readily available in most supermarkets. Soy milk does not naturally contain significant amounts of digestible <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a>. Many manufacturers of soy milk sell calcium-enriched products, as well. Soy is also used in <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a>: the beans (sometimes mixed with grain) are fermented into a solid cake.
</p><p>Soy products also are used as a low-cost substitute in meat and poultry products.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> Food service, retail and institutional (primarily school lunch and correctional) facilities regularly use such "extended" products. Extension may result in diminished flavor, but fat and cholesterol are reduced. Vitamin and mineral fortification can be used to make soy products nutritionally equivalent to animal protein; the protein quality is already roughly equivalent. The soy-based meat substitute <a href="/wiki/Textured_vegetable_protein" title="Textured vegetable protein">textured vegetable protein</a> has been used for more than 50&#160;years as a way of inexpensively extending <a href="/wiki/Ground_beef" title="Ground beef">ground beef</a> without reducing its nutritional value.<sup id="cite_ref-Riaz2006_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Riaz2006-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NSRL_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NSRL-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_products">Other products</span></h3>
<p>Soybeans with black hulls are the beans used in Chinese fermented black beans, <i><a href="/wiki/Douchi" title="Douchi">douchi</a></i>, not the sometimes confused <a href="/wiki/Black_turtle_bean" title="Black turtle bean">black turtle beans</a>.
</p><p>Soybeans are also used in industrial products, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oil (page does not exist)">oils</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soap" title="Soap">Soap</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics" title="Cosmetics">Cosmetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Resin" title="Resin">resins</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plastic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plastic (page does not exist)">plastics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ink" title="Ink">inks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crayon" title="Crayon">crayons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solvent" title="Solvent">solvents</a>, and clothing. Soybean oil is the primary source of <a href="/wiki/Biodiesel" title="Biodiesel">biodiesel</a> in the United States, accounting for 80% of domestic biodiesel production.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> Soybeans have also been used since 2001 as fermenting stock in the manufacture of a brand of <a href="/wiki/Vodka" title="Vodka">vodka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> In 1936, Ford Motor Company developed a method where soybeans and fibers were rolled together producing a soup which was then pressed into various parts for their cars, from the distributor cap to knobs on the dash board. Ford also informed in public relation releases that in 1935 over five million acres (20,000&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) was dedicated to growing soybeans in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-PM_Apr_1936_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PM_Apr_1936-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cattle_feed">Cattle feed</span></h3>
<p>Cattle are often fed soy. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vernal_grass&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vernal grass (page does not exist)">Spring grasses</a> are rich in omega-3 fatty acids, whereas soy is predominantly omega-6.
</p>
