<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_benefits">Health benefits</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cancer">Cancer</span></h3>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/American_Cancer_Society" title="American Cancer Society">American Cancer Society</a>, "Studies in humans have not shown harm from eating soy foods. Moderate consumption of soy foods appears safe for both breast cancer survivors and the general population, and may even lower breast cancer risk." They caution however that soy supplements should be avoided.<sup id="cite_ref-acs_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-acs-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Brain">Brain</span></h3>
<p>Recent studies have shown improvement in postmenopausal women's cognitive function, particularly verbal memory,<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> and in <a href="/wiki/Frontal_lobe" title="Frontal lobe">frontal lobe</a> function<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> with the use of soy supplements.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Alpha-linolenic_acid">Alpha-linolenic acid</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Trader_joes_edamame.jpg" title="File:Trader joes edamame.jpg">File:Trader joes edamame.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Roasted soybeans</div></div></div>
<p>Soybean oil is one of the  vegetable oils that contain a significant amount of the <a href="/wiki/Omega-3" title="Omega-3" class="mw-redirect">omega-3</a> fatty acid <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha-linolenic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha-linolenic acid (page does not exist)">alpha-linolenic acid</a> (18:3n−3, aLNA). Other plant oils containing aLNA (or ALA) include <a href="/wiki/Canola" title="Canola">canola</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walnut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walnut (page does not exist)">walnut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hemp" title="Hemp">hemp</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Flax" title="Flax">flax</a>. Soybean oil has an omega-3:omega-6 ratio of 1:7. This is a significantly higher omega-3 content than in other vegetable cooking oils. While <a href="/wiki/Flaxseed" title="Flaxseed" class="mw-redirect">flaxseed</a> is even higher with a ratio of 3:1, it is not practical for cooking. For more information on the health benefits of <a href="/wiki/Omega-3" title="Omega-3" class="mw-redirect">omega-3</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Omega-6&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Omega-6 (page does not exist)">omega-6</a> <a href="/wiki/Fatty_acids" title="Fatty acids" class="mw-redirect">fatty acids</a>, see <a href="/wiki/Essential_fatty_acids" title="Essential fatty acids" class="mw-redirect">Essential fatty acids</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_phenols">Natural phenols</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Isoflavones">Isoflavones</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Soybeans also contain the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isoflavone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isoflavone (page does not exist)">isoflavones</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genistein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genistein (page does not exist)">genistein</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daidzein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daidzein (page does not exist)">daidzein</a>, types of <a href="/wiki/Phytoestrogen" title="Phytoestrogen" class="mw-redirect">phytoestrogen</a>, that are considered by some dietitians and physicians to be useful in the prevention of cancer and by others to be carcinogenic<sup id="cite_ref-cardio_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cardio-95">[95]</a></sup> and endocrine disruptive.<sup id="cite_ref-ab1_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ab1-96">[96]</a></sup>
Soy's content of isoflavones are as much as 3&#160;mg/g dry weight.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> Isoflavones are polyphenol compounds, produced primarily by beans and other legumes, including peanuts and <a href="/wiki/Chickpea" title="Chickpea">chickpeas</a>. Isoflavones are closely related to the antioxidant <a href="/wiki/Flavonoid" title="Flavonoid">flavonoids</a> found in other plants, vegetables and flowers. Isoflavones such as genistein and daidzein are found in only some plant families, because most plants do not have an enzyme, chalcone isomerase which converts a flavone precursor into an isoflavone.
</p><p>In contradiction to well known benefits of isoflavones, genistein acts as an oxidant (stimulating nitrate synthesis),<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> and blocks formation of new blood vessels (antiangiogenic effect).<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> Some studies show that genistein acts as inhibitor of substances that regulate cell division and cell survival (growth factors).
</p><p>A review of the available studies by the United States <a href="/wiki/Health_and_Human_Services" title="Health and Human Services" class="mw-redirect">Health and Human Services</a> <a href="/wiki/Agency_for_Healthcare_Research_and_Quality" title="Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality">Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality</a> (AHRQ) found little evidence of substantial health improvements and no adverse effects, but also noted that there was no long-term safety data on estrogenic effects from soy consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-AHRQ_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AHRQ-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Glyceollins">Glyceollins</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glyceollin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glyceollin (page does not exist)">Glyceollins</a> are molecules belonging to the pterocarpans family. They are also found in the soybean and have been found to have an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antifungal_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antifungal protein (page does not exist)">antifungal</a> activity against <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aspergillus_sojae&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aspergillus sojae (page does not exist)">Aspergillus sojae</a></i>, the fungal ferment used to produce soy sauce.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> They are <a href="/wiki/Phytoalexin" title="Phytoalexin">phytoalexins</a> with an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antiestrogenic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antiestrogenic (page does not exist)">antiestrogenic</a> activity.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cholesterol_and_heart_diseases">Cholesterol and heart diseases</span></h3>
<p>The dramatic increase in soyfood sales is largely credited to the <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration" title="Food and Drug Administration">Food and Drug Administration</a>'s (FDA) approval of soy as an official cholesterol-lowering food, along with other heart and health benefits.<sup id="cite_ref-CU_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CU-103">[103]</a></sup> A 2001 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Literature_review&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Literature review (page does not exist)">literature review</a> argued that these health benefits were poorly supported by the available evidence, and noted that disturbing data on soy's effect on the cognitive function of the elderly existed.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> In 2008, an epidemiological study of 719 Indonesian elderly found that tofu intake was associated with worse memory, but <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a> (a fermented soy product) intake was associated with better memory.<sup id="cite_ref-Hogervorst_E.2C_Sadjimim_T.2C_Yesufu_A.2C_Kreager_P.2C_Rahardjo_TB_2008_50.E2.80.937_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hogervorst_E.2C_Sadjimim_T.2C_Yesufu_A.2C_Kreager_P.2C_Rahardjo_TB_2008_50.E2.80.937-105">[105]</a></sup> This study replicated other studies.
</p><p>In 1995, the <i>New England Journal of Medicine</i> (Vol. 333, No. 5) published "Meta-analysis of the effects of soy protein intake on serum lipids",<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> financed in part by DuPont Protein Technologies International (PTI), which produces and markets soy through The Solae Company (see external links). The meta-analysis concluded that soy protein is correlated with significant decreases in serum cholesterol, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Low_Density_Lipoprotein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Low Density Lipoprotein (page does not exist)">LDL</a> (bad cholesterol) and triglycerides. However, <a href="/w/index.php?title=High_Density_Lipoprotein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High Density Lipoprotein (page does not exist)">HDL</a> (good cholesterol) did not increase by a significant amount. Soy <a href="/wiki/Phytoestrogens" title="Phytoestrogens">phytoestrogens</a> (<a href="/wiki/Isoflavones" title="Isoflavones">isoflavones</a>: genistein and daidzein) <a href="/wiki/Adsorbed" title="Adsorbed" class="mw-redirect">adsorbed</a> onto the soy protein were suggested as the agent reducing serum cholesterol levels. On the basis of this research PTI filed a petition with FDA in 1998 for a health claim that soy protein may reduce cholesterol and the risk of heart disease.
</p><p>The FDA granted the following health claim for soy: "25 grams of soy protein a day, as part of a diet low in saturated fat and cholesterol, may reduce the risk of heart disease."<sup id="cite_ref-FDA_Claims_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FDA_Claims-20">[20]</a></sup> One serving, (1 cup or 240 mL) of soy milk, for instance, contains 6 or 7&#160;grams of soy protein. Solae resubmitted their original petition, asking for a more vague health claim, after their original was challenged and highly criticized. Solae also submitted a petition for a health claim that soy can help prevent cancer. They quickly withdrew the petition for lack of evidence and after more than 1,000 letters of protest were received. On February 18, 2008 Weston A. Price Foundation submitted a petition for removal of this health claim.<sup id="cite_ref-westonaprice_fda_petition_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-westonaprice_fda_petition-107">[107]</a></sup> 25 g/day soy protein was established as the threshold intake because most trials used at least this much protein and not because less than this amount is inefficacious. In fact, there is evidence suggesting that lower amounts are indeed efficacious.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>An American Heart Association review of a decade long study of soy protein benefits casts doubt on the FDA allowed "Heart Healthy" claim for soy protein and does not recommend isoflavone supplementation. The review panel also found that soy isoflavones have not been shown to reduce post menopause "hot flashes" in women and the efficacy and safety of isoflavones to help prevent cancers of the breast, uterus or prostate is in question. However, AHA concludes that "many soy products should be beneficial to cardiovascular and overall health because of their high content of polyunsaturated fats, fiber, vitamins, and minerals and low content of saturated fat".<sup id="cite_ref-cardio_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cardio-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>Importantly, however, the AHA did not conduct a formal statistical analysis of the 22 studies upon which they based their estimate of the potency of soy protein. When such an analysis was conducted, Jenkins et al.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> found that the AHA had considerably underestimated the hypocholesterolemic effects of soy protein. Further, when the analysis was limited to the 11 studies that provided evidence that the control and soy diets were matched, soy protein was found to lower LDL by 5.2 percent. This estimate is in line with the results of other recently published meta-analyses.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> Furthermore, recent research suggests that soy protein decreases postprandial triglyceride levels, which is increasingly viewed as important for reducing CHD risk.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Phytic_acid">Phytic acid</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Soybeans contain a high level of phytic acid, which has many effects including acting as an antioxidant and a chelating agent. The beneficial claims for phytic acid include reducing cancer,<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> minimizing diabetes,<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> and reducing inflammation.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> However, phytic acid is also criticized for reducing vital minerals due to its chelating effect, especially for diets already low in minerals.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_risks">Health risks</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Allergy">Allergy</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Allergy to soy is common, and the food is listed with other foods that commonly cause allergy, such as milk, eggs, peanuts, tree nuts, shellfish. The problem has been reported among younger children, and the diagnosis of soy allergy is often based on symptoms reported by parents and/or results of skin tests or blood tests for allergy. Only a few reported studies have attempted to confirm allergy to soy by direct challenge with the food under controlled conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> It is very difficult to give a reliable estimate of the true prevalence of soy allergy in the general population. To the extent that it does exist, soy allergy may cause cases of <a href="/wiki/Urticaria" title="Urticaria">urticaria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Angioedema" title="Angioedema">angioedema</a>, usually within minutes to hours of ingestion. In rare cases, true <a href="/wiki/Anaphylaxis" title="Anaphylaxis">anaphylaxis</a> may also occur. The reason for the discrepancy is likely that soy proteins, the causative factor in allergy, are far less potent at triggering allergy symptoms than the proteins of peanut and shellfish.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> An allergy test that is positive demonstrates that the immune system has formed IgE antibodies to soy proteins. However, this is only a factor when soy proteins reach the blood without being digested, in sufficient quantities to reach a threshold to provoke actual symptoms.
</p><p>Soy can also trigger symptoms via <a href="/wiki/Food_intolerance" title="Food intolerance">food intolerance</a>, a situation where no allergic mechanism can be proven. One scenario is seen in very young infants who have vomiting and <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrhoea</a> when fed soy-based formula, which resolves when the formula is withdrawn. Older infants can suffer a more severe disorder with vomiting, diarrhoea that may be bloody, <a href="/wiki/Anemia" title="Anemia">anemia</a>, weight loss and failure to thrive. The most common cause of this unusual disorder is a sensitivity to cow's milk, but soy formulas can also be the trigger. The precise mechanism is unclear and it could be immunologic, although not through the IgE-type antibodies that have the leading role in urticaria and anaphylaxis. However it is also self-limiting and will often disappear in the <a href="/wiki/Toddler" title="Toddler">toddler</a> years.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Phytoestrogen">Phytoestrogen</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Soybeans contain <a href="/wiki/Isoflavones" title="Isoflavones">isoflavones</a> called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genistein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genistein (page does not exist)">genistein</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daidzein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daidzein (page does not exist)">daidzein</a>, which are one source of <a href="/wiki/Phytoestrogens" title="Phytoestrogens">phytoestrogens</a> in the human diet. Because most naturally occurring estrogenic substances show weak activity, normal consumption of foods that contain these phytoestrogens should not provide sufficient amounts to elicit a physiological response in humans.<sup id="cite_ref-pmid11352776_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid11352776-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>Plant <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lignans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lignans (page does not exist)">lignans</a> associated with high fiber foods such as cereal brans and beans are the principal precursor to mammalian lignans which have an ability to bind to human estrogen sites. Soybeans are a significant source of mammalian lignan precursor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Secoisolariciresinol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Secoisolariciresinol (page does not exist)">secoisolariciresinol</a> containing 13–273&#160;µg/100&#160;g dry weight.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> Another phytoestrogen in the human diet with estrogen activity is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coumestans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coumestans (page does not exist)">coumestans</a>, which are found in beans, split-peas, with the best sources being alfalfa, clover, and soybean sprouts. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coumestrol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coumestrol (page does not exist)">Coumestrol</a>, an isoflavone <a href="/wiki/Coumarin" title="Coumarin">coumarin</a> derivative is the only coumestan in foods.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Soybeans and processed soy foods are among the richest foods in total phytoestrogens (wet basis per 100g), which are present primarily in the form of the isoflavones daidzein and genistein.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Women">Women</span></h4>
<p>A 2001&#160;literature review suggested that women with current or past breast cancer should be aware of the risks of potential tumor growth when taking soy products, based on the effect of phytoestrogens to promote breast cancer cell growth in animals.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> A 2006 commentary reviewed the relationship with soy and breast cancer. They stated that soy may decrease the risk of breast cancer, but cautioned that the impact of isoflavones on breast tissue needs to be evaluated at the cellular level in women at high risk for breast cancer.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> A high consumption of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Omega-6&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Omega-6 (page does not exist)">omega-6</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Polyunsaturated_fatty_acids&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Polyunsaturated fatty acids (page does not exist)">polyunsaturated fatty acids</a>, which are found in most types of <a href="/wiki/Vegetable_oil" title="Vegetable oil">vegetable oil</a> including soybean oil, may increase the likelihood that postmenopausal women will develop breast cancer.<sup id="cite_ref-Sonestedt_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sonestedt-128">[128]</a></sup> Another analysis suggests an inverse association between total polyunsaturated fatty acids and breast cancer risk.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> A 2011 analysis of the literature said: "Our study suggests soy isoflavones intake is associated with a significant reduced risk of breast cancer incidence in Asian populations, but not in Western populations."<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a recent (August 2011) trial the daily administration of tablets containing 200&#160;mg of soy isoflavones for 2 years did not prevent bone loss or menopausal symptoms.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Men">Men</span></h4>
<p>Because of the phytoestrogen content, some studies have suggested that soybean ingestion may influence <a href="/wiki/Testosterone" title="Testosterone">testosterone</a> levels in men. However, a 2010 meta-analysis of 15 placebo controlled studies showed that neither soy foods nor isoflavone supplements alter measures of bioavailable <a href="/wiki/Testosterone" title="Testosterone">testosterone</a> or <a href="/wiki/Estrogen" title="Estrogen">estrogen</a> concentrations in men.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> It has been hypothesized that soy foods and enterolactone may increase the development of <a href="/wiki/Prostate_cancer" title="Prostate cancer">prostate cancer</a> although no significant associations were observed for the soy isoflavones.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> Furthermore, soy consumption has been shown to have no effect on the levels and quality of <a href="/wiki/Sperm" title="Sperm">sperm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> A 2009 meta-analysis of the research on the association between soy consumption and prostate cancer risk in men concluded that "consumption of soy foods is associated with a reduction in prostate cancer risk in men."<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Brain_2">Brain</span></h3>
<p>Though there is some evidence that estrogen can help protect and repair the brain after injury in rats,<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> there is also evidence that phytoestrogens may be harmful for the recovery of rats in other situations<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> that have sustained brain injury.
</p><p>Similarly, epidemiological evidence of humans eating soya products is currently divided: a study of Japanese men between 1965 and 1999 demonstrated a positive correlation between brain atrophy and consumption of tofu meals,<sup id="cite_ref-pmid10763906_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid10763906-139">[139]</a></sup> and a study on elderly Indonesian men and women found that high tofu intake was associated with poorer memory, but the consumption of <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a> was associated with better memory.<sup id="cite_ref-Hogervorst_E.2C_Sadjimim_T.2C_Yesufu_A.2C_Kreager_P.2C_Rahardjo_TB_2008_50.E2.80.937_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hogervorst_E.2C_Sadjimim_T.2C_Yesufu_A.2C_Kreager_P.2C_Rahardjo_TB_2008_50.E2.80.937-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>So it may be that the type of soya bean used, or its preparation or additional ingredients are relevant factors, there is not yet definitive evidence known.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Carcinogenicity">Carcinogenicity</span></h3>
<p>Though raw <a href="#Flour">soy flour</a> is known to cause <a href="/wiki/Pancreatic_cancer" title="Pancreatic cancer">pancreatic cancer</a> in rats<sup id="cite_ref-ToxSci_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ToxSci-141">[141]</a></sup> the cooked flour has not been found <a href="/wiki/Carcinogen" title="Carcinogen">carcinogenic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CanRes_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CanRes-142">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AdvExp_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AdvExp-143">[143]</a></sup> Whether soy might promote pancreatic cancer in humans is unknown because studies have not yet attempted to single out soy intake and the incidence of pancreatic cancer in humans, and the amount of soy fed to the rats is proportionately far larger than what humans would normally consume. However, the soy isoflavone genistein has been suggested as a chemopreventive agent against pancreatic cancer, by interfering with the chemical pathways that promote the creation and growth of tumors.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Cancer Council of <a href="/wiki/New_South_Wales" title="New South Wales">New South Wales</a>, Australia has released a statement saying scientific research suggests that overall the moderate consumption of soy products does not appear to present a risk to women with breast cancer, and there is equivocal evidence that consuming large amounts of soy products may have a protective effect against developing breast and prostate cancer. However, the Council does not recommend taking soy <a href="/wiki/Dietary_supplement" title="Dietary supplement">dietary supplements</a> as there is no evidence they are either effective or safe at preventing or treating cancers.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gout">Gout</span></h3>
<p>Soybeans and soy products contain significant amounts of <a href="/wiki/Purines" title="Purines" class="mw-redirect">purines</a>, a class of organic compounds. For people who suffer from <a href="/wiki/Gout" title="Gout">gout</a>, eating foods containing moderate or high levels of purines might make the condition worse. The <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">U.S. National Institutes of Health</a> (NIH) recommends that gout sufferers limit consumption of soy products (although also suggesting that soy may have health benefits by reducing the risk for heart disease).<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> However, other researchers have found little or no association between consumption of purine-rich vegetables (including beans) and gout.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Soybean_futures">Soybean futures</span></h2>
<p>Soybean <a href="/wiki/Futures_contract" title="Futures contract">futures</a> are traded on the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Board_of_Trade" title="Chicago Board of Trade">Chicago Board of Trade</a> and have delivery dates in January (F), March (H), May (K), July (N), August (Q), September (U), November (X).
</p><p>It is also traded on other commodity futures exchanges under different contract specifications:
</p>
<ul>
<li> SAFEX: <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_South_African_Futures_Exchange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The South African Futures Exchange (page does not exist)">The South African Futures Exchange</a><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> DC: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dalian_Commodity_Exchange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dalian Commodity Exchange (page does not exist)">Dalian Commodity Exchange</a><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> KEX: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kansai_Commodities_Exchange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kansai Commodities Exchange (page does not exist)">Kansai Commodities Exchange</a> in Japan<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> TGE: Tokyo Grain Exchange in Japan<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> KCX: Fukuoka Commodity Exchange in Japan that was absorbed by the KEX
</li>
<li> NCDEX: National Commodity and Derivatives Exchange, India.
</li>
<li> ROFEX: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.rofex.com.ar/">Rosario Grain Exchange in Argentina</a>
</li>
</ul>

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soy_allergy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soy allergy (page does not exist)">Soy allergy</a>
</li>

</li>

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soybean_in_Paraguay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soybean in Paraguay (page does not exist)">Soybean in Paraguay</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Works_cited">Works cited</span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_doi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite doi (page does not exist)">Template:Cite doi</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Americana_Poster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Americana Poster (page does not exist)">Template:Americana Poster</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://biodiversity.ucoz.ru/index/genetic_resources_of_leguminous_plants_in_the_n_i_vavilov_institute_of_plant_industry/0-10">[1]</a> - Genetic Resources of Leguminous Plants in the N.I. Vavilov Institute of Plant Industry
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:DMOZ&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:DMOZ (page does not exist)">Template:DMOZ</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:DMOZ&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:DMOZ (page does not exist)">Template:DMOZ</a>
</li>
<li> New Crop Resource Online Program – Large collection of Soybean information
</li>
<li> Soybeans:complete listings  Intech Open Science.. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.intechopen.com/search?q=soybeans">InTech Open Access Publisher - Open Science Open Minds | InTechOpen</a>
</li>
<li> The Solae Company, producer and marketer of soy; a joint venture of <a href="/wiki/DuPont" title="DuPont">DuPont</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bunge_Limited" title="Bunge Limited">Bunge Limited</a>. 
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Agriculture_country_lists&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Agriculture country lists (page does not exist)">Template:Agriculture country lists</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Soy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Soy (page does not exist)">Template:Soy</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Vegetarianism (page does not exist)">Template:Vegetarianism</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Bioenergy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Bioenergy (page does not exist)">Template:Bioenergy</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nuts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nuts (page does not exist)">Template:Nuts</a>
<br /><strong class="error mw-ext-cite-error">Cite error: <code>&lt;ref&gt;</code> tags exist, but no <code>&lt;references/&gt;</code> tag was found</strong>
</p>
